Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of comments:

  • General sentiment: Strong dissatisfaction with the current tipping culture. Many feel it’s overextended, coercive, and shifts labor costs from employers to customers.
  • Core principle most agree on: Tipping should be voluntary, tied to the quality of service, and not expected for minimal or no service.
  • Who should be tipped: Broad support for tipping in full-service restaurants and for delivery drivers; frequent pushback against tipping for counter service, pickup orders, coffee shops, and simple transactions.
  • Pay and policy changes favored:
  • Require employers to pay a living wage (at least full minimum wage for tipped workers) so income doesn’t hinge on tips.
  • Reduce or remove tipping prompts, especially pre-service prompts and intrusive tablet screens; add an easy “no tip” option; only prompt where real service is provided.
  • Replace tipping with built-in service charges or higher menu prices so workers are paid fairly without relying on tips. Some suggest modest service fees (around 10%) with optional additional tips.
  • Views on keeping tipping: A minority strongly supports tipping as an incentive for great service and regularly tips generously; a smaller subset endorses higher standard rates (e.g., 20–30%) or even mandatory tipping unless wages meet a specific floor.
  • Concerns raised:
  • Social pressure and “guilt tipping,” especially via POS tablets.
  • Unpredictable income for workers and confusion for customers about when/how much to tip.
  • Expansion of tipping requests to contexts that don’t involve meaningful service.
  • Less common or mixed ideas:
  • Make tipping fixed amounts rather than percentages for small bills.
  • Exempt tips from taxation or have employers match a portion of tips.
  • Provide small rewards for tipping (thank-you notes, coupons).
  • Establish clearer standards for who is tipped and when.

Bottom line: Most want to curb tip creep, ensure workers earn a stable, livable wage from employers, and reserve tipping as a discretionary bonus for clear, high-quality service—often limited to traditional, full-service contexts.

Summary B

Overall summary of comments:

  • General sentiment: Broad frustration with the current tipping culture. Many feel it’s overextended, pressured, and appearing in situations that don’t warrant it (counter service, pickup, simple transactions). Tipping before service and aggressive tablet prompts were frequent pain points.

  • Pay and responsibility: A strong majority want employers to pay a fair, livable wage and to end the sub-minimum “tipped wage,” so tips return to being a bonus for exceptional service rather than a wage substitute.

  • Where tipping belongs: Many want tipping limited to full-service dining and delivery. Counter service, coffee shops, and simple pickups were commonly cited as contexts where tipping should be optional or not requested.

  • How tipping should work: Most prefer tipping to be voluntary and tied to quality of service, not mandatory or “expected.” Some propose service-inclusive pricing or a modest automatic service charge (often cited at around 10%), with discretionary tipping on top for exceptional service. A smaller group supports keeping or even increasing standard tip levels (20–30%) as performance incentives.

  • Point-of-sale practices: People want clearer, less coercive interfaces—easy-to-find “no tip” options, no auto-prompts in low-service contexts, and tipping requested only after service is rendered.

  • Standardization and alternative ideas: Suggestions included eliminating taxes on tips, employers matching a portion of tips, fixed amount tips rather than percentages for small bills, setting fair suggested ranges, and adopting European or Japanese-style models (service charge built in, no tipping).

  • Equity and predictability: Commenters noted tipping’s unpredictability for workers and the social pressure on consumers. Many prefer stable wages with transparent pricing, allowing tips to function as genuine appreciation rather than obligation.

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?
